Award.AwardTitle: EAPSI:Understanding the Genetic and Protein Dynamics Involved in the Seasonally Breeding Japanese Macaque
Award.AbstractNarration:
Research that works to enhance the understanding of the genes, proteins, and processes involved in primate reproduction is important for shaping both evolutionary and biomedical knowledge. This award supports research to examine the Japanese macaque as a primate model for gamete production, with emphasis on the genetic and protein dynamics involved in its seasonal-breeding ability. Male Japanese macaques shut down reproductive functions in the birthing season and resume function in the breeding season, challenging previous thinking that gamete production was highly conserved across mammals. Recent research has shown differences in genetic and molecular dynamics between rodent and primate models. This emphasizes the need to develop primate models, which are more closely related to humans, in order to make more accurate extrapolations to human reproductive biology. This project will be conducted under the mentorship of Dr. Hirohisa Hirai, a noted molecular biologist and primatologist, at the Primate Research Institute (PRI) in Inuyama, Japan, home to extensive collections of preserved Japanese macaque tissue which will be invaluable to this research.

Previous research has focused on the hormonal and cellular pathways involved in the suppression of testicular function in Japanese macaques, but the underlying genetic and molecular mechanisms remain elusive. The project will focus on three potential mechanisms: i) the quiescence of sperm proliferation, ii) apoptosis in the testes, and iii) stage-specific cessation of sperm production. Testis tissue collected from males in both the breeding and birthing seasons will be analyzed for spermatogenesis genes, germ cell markers, and epigenetic states using RT-PCR. Then, the researcher will use HE-staining and immunofluorescence microscopy to gain a clear spatiotemporal understanding about the dynamics of primate reproduction.

This award under the East Asia and Pacific Summer Institutes program supports summer research by a U.S. graduate student and is jointly funded by NSF and the Japan Society for the Promotion of Science (JSPS).

POR.DRECONTENT:
Human males are reproductively active year round, but that is not the case for a closely related primate species, the Japanese macaque.  These primate males undergo distinct seasonal spermatogenesis.  The genetic mechanisms of this process remain elusive and the exploration of these mechanisms can illuminate both evolutionary and biomedical insights into primate reproductive biology.

Through a 2016 NSF EAPSI grant in collaboration with JSPS, I was able to work with a leading researcher, Dr. Masanori Imamura, in the field of primate genetics.  At the Primate Research Institute of Kyoto Univeristy, I learned Reverse Transcriptase PCR and immunohistochemistry which are two techniques that allowed me to determine what and where particular genes are being expressed.  Under Dr. Imamura's tutelage, I collected initial data which will help develop a comprehensive genetic profile for the seasonal sperm production of the Japanese macaque.  By understanding what genes are being expressed and in what part of the male reproductive system in this primate model, we can continue to uncover genetic and molecular mechanisms responsible for the cessation and resumption of male fertility. 

Learning these advanced molecular techniques will aid in my continued graduate research and future professional development.  My current research focuses on spermatogenesis genes located on the Y chromosome of the rhesus macaque - an important primate research model. With RT-PCR and immunohistochemistry added to my molecular biology skill set, further research opportunities are now possible as I continue my scientific development.

Lastly, engaging in an international research collaboration with a leading researcher from Japan has been an invaluable opportunity.  I have shared my experiences through a weekly online blog (https://www.kent.edu/anthropology/student-blogs) in the hopes of disseminating STEM research to the broader public.  I have also given talks to both fellow academics - Kyushu University Dept. of Environmental Changes, Kent State University Dept. of Anthropology, Kent St. International Education Week -  and to STEM students of Barstow High School, CA, from my home town.
